sols_html:
First, let’s compute the matrix B

\[\begin{aligned} B &= A^2 + 3A + 2I \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc} -6 & 8 \\ -4 & 6 \end{array}\right]\left[ \begin{array}{cc} -6 & 8 \\ -4 & 6 \end{array}\right] + 3 \left[ \begin{array}{cc} -6 & 8 \\ -4 & 6 \end{array}\right] + 2 \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 4 \end{array}\right] + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} -18 & 24 \\ -12 & 18 \end{array}\right] + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 2 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{array}\right] \\ &= \left[ \begin{array}{cc} -12 & 24 \\ -12 & 24 \end{array}\right]\end{aligned}\]

And clearly this matrix has determinant zero.

Note: this is a more fancy solution, no worries if you don’t like it as much.

The matrix B is a polynomial in the matrix A that we can factor as

\[\begin{aligned} B &= A^2 + 3A + 2I \\ &= (A+I)(A+2I)\end{aligned}\]

And since the determinant is multiplicative, we have that

\[\begin{aligned} \det(B) &= \det((A+I)(A+2I)) \\ &= \det(A+I) \det(A+2I)\end{aligned}\]

Now in part (a) we saw that -2 is an eigenvalue and hence the determinant of \(A+2I\) is zero and thus so is the determinant of the matrix B.
